RT @RepBrownley Just as the Floyd family has been forever changed, our society must change too. We must take action to address the excessive use of force and ensure accountability. This is the moral imperative that these times call for.

RT @RepBrownley For far too long, the Black community has cried out for racial justice and police reform. While today‚Äôs verdict provides hope in our continued fight for justice and what is right, our work to honor George Floyd‚Äôs life, and the lives of countless others, is far from over.

RT @RepBonamici Today his family got justice, but this verdict cannot bring back George Floyd. Black Americans have lived in fear for too long. The Senate must pass the #GeorgeFloydJusticeInPolicingAct to help end the targeting of Black communities by police.

RT @RepBonamici George Floyd‚Äôs murder is a tragedy and a painful chapter in our country‚Äôs history of systemic racism. His family and his community in Minneapolis have experienced heartbreaking anguish. They deserve accountability, and I wish them peace and healing.

RT @RepCasten While I hope that today‚Äôs verdict paves the way for increased accountability for police brutality, it is also my hope that it doesn‚Äôt dissuade us from reckoning with the reality facing Black and Brown Americans or the long way we have left to go.

RT @RepCasten For Americans who watched for more than 9 minutes and 29 seconds as George Floyd was murdered, this trial wasn‚Äôt so much a question of guilt as it was a test of the American justice system. Today, our justice system prevailed, but time and again it fails Americans of color.

RT @RepMikeLevin Justice has prevailed. Derek Chauvin will be held responsible for his actions, but that doesn‚Äôt change the fact that George Floyd should be alive today. We must do more to improve policing & hold law enforcement accountable. We must pass the George Floyd Justice in Policing Act.

RT @RepMcEachin We must commit to changing our policing to ensure these kinds of incidents do not happen again, are not continual headlines and that families are not left shocked and grieving when a loved one doesn‚Äôt come home. And that is how we honor George Floyd‚Äôs life and countless others.

RT @RepMcEachin This verdict, while, frankly,  a relief that the system worked this time and a moment of acknowledgement that George Floyd‚Äôs life was egregiously and heinously snuffed out, is not a solution.

RT @RepHuffman Today, justice was served and the calls of millions of Americans demanding action were answered. George Floyd‚Äôs life mattered‚Äîall #BlackLivesMatter.  I am thinking of George Floyd‚Äôs family and the small sense of peace this verdict hopefully brings them. [1/]

Vice President Mondale was the true embodiment of a public servant. His integrity, patriotism and enduring kindness came to define his years in elective office and left our country stronger and more prosperous. From one proud Midwesterner to another, may he Rest In Peace.

He had chosen Geraldine Ferraro, the first woman to be nominated, as his running mate, and I thought that was very, very cool. Even though making that history was a crucial milestone for women, it was by no means the only highlight of his career.

It was in the run-up to the 1984 election and my elementary school was holding a mock vote. I knew my dad was voting for Ronald Reagan, so that was my plan ‚Äî but once I went into the voting booth and pulled the curtain shut around me, I secretly cast my ballot for Walter Mondale
